artificial enzymes 6.2.1 Easy construction of complicated catalytic systems 6.2.2 Control of catalytic activity by external stimulus 6.3 Use of multimers of proteins for the construction of artificial Graphical abstract Conversions of materials, energies, and various signals are important keys in science and technology to solve various problems in current society. Catalysis is the main concept to efficiently promote such conversions. As the most sophisticated systems to achieve various conversions, biological systems have been satisfactorily developed where biological catalysts, enzymes, play important roles. Therefore, catalytic systems with bio-like functions reasonably create advanced conversion systems for various demands. In this review article, basics of artificial enzymes and their recent progresses are overviewed on the basis of emerging concept, nanoarchitectonics. First, classical scientific efforts and basics for enzyme models are described, and then practically applicable artificial enzymes are presented. The latter part involves nanomaterials, DNA and peptides, modifications of their nanoarchitectures, and constructions of complicated and stimuli-responsive systems. We expect that overviewing artificial enzymes with the nanoarchitectonics concept would be useful to get intuitions for catalysts designs and their syntheses. Keywords Artificial enzyme Catalyst DNA Nanoarchitectonics Nanozyme 1 Introduction: nanoarchitectonics for molecular catalysis Most of social demands related to devices, materials, energy, and environmental and biomedical problems are based on various conversion events for chemicals, photons, electrons, and energies [1–5]. Current sciences and technologies try to solves these problems though organic syntheses [6–12], energy/electron managements [13–15] such as batteries [16–18] fuel cells [19–21] and solar cells [22–24], photo and thermal energy transformations [25–27], and biological treatments [28–31]. The most important key player in these processes would be catalysis. Catalysis is a central concept to make these conversions efficiently and target specifically, as seen in various catalysts including organic synthetic catalysts to produce functional molecules [32–36] and polymers [37–39], electrochemical catalysts [40–42], photocatalysts [43–46], environmental green catalysts [47–50], and biocatalysts [51–53]. Investigations for catalysts with better performances originally depend on searching good materials, but importance of structural regulations based on nanostructure controls and organic designs becomes more explicitly recognized [54–60]. Better catalytic performances can often be obtained on the basis of structural controls of size, lattice, interface, structures of ligands, and secondary motifs of biomaterials. In some cases, less expensive materials with well-designed structures bring high catalytic performances comparable to those of expensive stuffs such as precious metals and rare earth materials [61–63]. Therefore, good catalysts have to be designed and synthesized in many cases by combined consideration of nanoscience, materials science, organic chemistry, supramolecular chemistry, and biology. These interdisciplinary natures between wide range of science fields are similar to those of emerging concept, nanoarchitectonics (Fig. 1 ) [64–66]. The nanoarchitectonics was initially proposed by Masakazu Aono [67,68]. This concept proposes architecting functional materials from nanoscale units through combined effects of chemical synthesis, atom/molecule manipulation, chemical nano-manipulation, field-induced material control and self-assembly, and self-organization [69,70]. Basis of nanotechnology works together with the other scientific disciplines such as organic syntheses, supramolecular chemistry, materials science, and bio-nanotechnologies. In fact, the nanoarchitectonics concept have been used for designs and synthesis for catalysts including photocatalysts [71,72], environmental catalysts [73,74], electrochemical catalysts [75,76], and bio-catalysts [77] as well as applications of nanoarchitectonics to other targets such as materials production [78–81], structural regulations [82,83], devices [84,85], sensors [86,87], energy [88–91], environmental science [92,93], and biological/biomedical fields [94–97]. Other distinct features of the nanoarchitectonics concept would be its dynamic and harmonized natures [98–100]. Because various uncertainties including thermal fluctuation, static distributions, and quantum effects are unavoidable and uncontrollable in nanoscale size regions, considerations based on balanced harmonization including certain dynamisms are important in the nanoarchitectonics concept. This dynamic aspect of nanoarchitectonics is rather close to that observed in biological systems [101,102] where functional components are dynamically working together in their harmonization. Therefore, nanoarchitectonics may work well on designs and syntheses of catalysts for biological functions. Catalysts for biological functions and biomimetic actions are widely known as artificial enzymes. Science and technology for artificial enzymes may include nanoarchitectonics essences although we did not much recognize this point before. In this review article, basics and recent progresses of artificial enzymes are overviewed. It starts with descriptions on classical scientific efforts and basics for enzyme models and switches to practically applicable artificial enzymes. The latter involves nanomaterials, DNA and peptides and modifications of their nanoarchitectures and constructions of complicated and stimuli-responsive systems, as well as novel membrane type enzyme (L-zyme). We expect that overviewing the features of artificial enzymes, with the nanoarchitectonics concept, would be useful to get intuitions for catalysts designs and syntheses. 2 Preparation of “classical enzyme models” 2.1 Dawn of biomimetic chemistry Remarkably high activity of naturally occurring enzymes, as well as their surprisingly high specificity (with respect to both substrate and product), has been attracting great interests and respects for a long time. People were wondering what kinds of mechanisms are going on in enzymes, and at the same time wanted to prepare man-made tools which accomplish comparable (or even better) functions. In those days, however, the information on the structures of enzymes was too scarce to design their mimics. Furthermore, the technology to synthesize the compounds of desired structures and properties was too poor. Accordingly, preparation of enzyme mimics was simply a dream. It was only in 1950s that chemists started apparent attempts to mimic the functions of enzymes by chemical means (this new field was named as biomimetic chemistry). The purposes of these attempts are divided into two categories. One is to deepen our understanding on the reaction mechanisms of enzymes. Naturally occurring enzymes are so huge and complicated that their direct analysis was almost impossible (this is primarily true even at present). By subjecting “enzyme models” to advanced analytical means, detailed and precise information can be obtained. Another purpose is to prepare artificial tools which are more stable and cheaper than naturally occurring enzymes. Furthermore, in terms of biomimetic chemistry, we should be able to obtain novel tools for the reactions which we must accomplish to make our lives more healthy, comfortable, and fruitful, but cannot find appropriate enzymes in the nature. These man-made tools can be freely designed in chemical approaches. Fortunately, the mechanisms of non-enzymatic catalysis were gradually being understood at that time [103,104]. Importance of acid and/or base catalysis was evidenced in detail in a number of reactions (also in enzymatic reactions). Due to remarkable progresses in the technique of X-ray crystallography, structural data of many enzymes were accumulated, and facilitated our atomic level understanding of reaction mechanisms. Furthermore, genetic engineering has become popular, and supplied to chemists and others raw materials such as proteins, DNA, and cells in large amounts. At the same time, abundant information has rapidly become available to allow us to make precise molecular design of the mimics. Commercialization of DNA synthesizers and peptide synthesizers also prompted the trend. By the combination of all these factors, the studies on artificial enzymes have made remarkable progresses. 2.2 Basic principle of classic design As is now well known, remarkable activities of enzymes are primarily attributable to both (i) highly selective binding of specific substrate and (ii) efficient transformation of the substrates to desired products. Among many substrates in the solutions, only the specific substrate is selectively bound by the binding-site, formed by the main-chains and side-chains of proteins, and is accumulated near the catalytic center composed of multiple catalytic groups. In the catalytic center, these catalytic groups are correctly placed in highly specified orientations so that the efficiency of required chemical transformation is maximized. Mutual orientations of these catalytic groups, as well as the position of specific substrate, are optimized for effective acid/base cooperative catalysis and also for proton-transfer between them. In addition, the chemical environments around these catalytic groups (e.g., hydrophobicity, electrostatic fields, and others) are regulated to be most suitable for required catalysis. As the results, these functional groups in total show exceptionally effective catalysis. Importantly, the catalysis by enzymes works very effectively only on the specific substrate, because otherwise the spatial and chemical factors are rendered inappropriate. Thus, even when other substrates having similar structures to the specific substrate are bound by the enzyme, the transformation never smoothly occurs and in total this enzyme never shows remarkable activity. When necessary, cofactors (coenzymes and/or metal ions) are bound by the proteins (apoenzymes) and form holoenzymes to accomplish eminent catalysis. Because of the cooperation of all these factors, the specific substrates are transformed to predetermined products selectively and promptly. Based on these understandings, enzyme models were first constructed by using polymeric catalysts which bear catalytic groups in the side-chains (e.g., poly(vinylimidazole) and poly(vinylpyridine)). These polymers bind the substrates, usually through apolar interactions, prior to chemical transformation, and catalyze the reactions. This reaction scheme is identical with the one employed by enzymes, and the reaction rate follows Michaelis-Menten kinetics which characterizes enzymatic reactions. Hydrolysis of carboxylic acid esters was mostly analyzed because of experimental convenience (vide infra). Later, host molecules (e.g., cyclodextrins, cyclophanes, crown ethers, and others), which possess well-defined structures and bind guest molecules in a uniform ratio (usually 1:1), were used as substrate-binding sites [105–113]. The reactions using host molecules were far more suitable than polymer-catalyst systems to analyze catalytic mechanisms quantitatively and in detail. By attaching catalytic group(s) to the host molecules, still more advanced artificial enzymes were synthesized. For example, an imidazole was connected to cyclodextrin as a kind of the simplest model of α-chymotrypsin (Fig. 2 A), which catalyzes the hydrolysis of peptide substrates through general base-catalysis by an imidazole group of His residue [114]. Still more advanced mimic of α-chymotrypsin was prepared by attaching a model of charge-relay system (a consecutive proton-relay in Ser-His-Asp triad) to cyclodextrin (Fig. 2B) [115]. Furthermore, a mimic of ribonuclease A for RNA hydrolysis (which proceeds via acid/base cooperation of two His residues) was prepared by binding two imidazole molecules to cyclodextrin and taking advantage of their intramolecular acid-base cooperation (Fig. 2C) [116]. A number of artificial enzymes involving more complicated catalytic systems were also reported. All these works shed light on the mechanisms of naturally occurring enzymes, and the importance of these approaches has been well recognized in all the fields of science. Relevant studies are still being growing widely and rapidly, providing many excellent results [117–119]. 2.3 From classic to nanoarchitectonics: increasing roles of nanoarchitectonics in enzyme models More recently, biomimetic chemistry has been greatly changed by increasing participation of nanoarchitectonics which has developed so remarkably in this decade [120,121]. With this technology, microstructures of various materials can be regulated in nanometer-scale. Furthermore, desired functional groups can be placed at desired places even when they are mutually separated each other in nm-scaled distance. Thus, this technology is essential to satisfactorily mimic a variety of enzymes, most of which have spatial dimensions of several nanometers or larger. Without the use of nanoarchitectonics, the largest sizes controllable in the products are the sizes of host molecules (mostly less than 1 nm), and thus it is very difficult to mimic enzymes sufficiently. Furthermore, nanoarchitectures are constructed by self-assembly of small components, which can be synthesized in terms of freely designable structural variations. This is very advantageous to optimize the activity of products through detailed molecular design. Accordingly, the combination of biomimetic chemistry with nanoarchitectonics is highly promising to construct artificial enzymes which possess superb functions (see 6.2 for more details). In fact, unprecedented and novel substrate-binding sites and catalysts have emerged from nanoarchitectonics, and greatly widened the scope of biomimetic chemistry. New methodology to construct artificial enzymes has been also envisioned by the combination of two areas. The overlaps between these two areas are the primary subjects of this review. 3 From “enzyme models” to “practically applicable artificial enzymes” On the preparation of “classic enzyme models”, so many works were reported from many laboratories. In these studies, the primary concern of researchers was to imitate the structures of enzymes as much as possible. In almost all the cases, the catalytic groups employed were the ones used by the enzymes. Mutual orientations of these groups in the enzyme were mimicked as much as possible. With this strategy, many enzyme mimics were synthesized, and the mechanisms of enzymatic catalysis were successfully clarified in detail. As the results, our understanding on the secrets of enzymes for unbelievably remarkable functions was greatly enriched and deepened. Thus, one of the goals of these studies in biomimetic chemistry (the purpose (i) in Section 2) was, at least partially, accomplished. However, few of these artificial enzymes were applicable to practical purposes, since the factors other than “similarity to enzymes” were of secondary concerns there. Thus, another goal of the studies (developments of practically useful tools on the basis of enzyme models) was not sufficiently fulfilled in several aspects. First, the scope of reactions catalyzed by these mimics was significantly limited. Most of these studies employed ester hydrolysis, primarily due to experimental convenience. These reactions were chosen, simply because they proceed with sufficient reaction rates and can be easily followed by spectroscopic means (for example, hydrolysis of phenyl esters accompanies measurable changes in UV–vis absorption). Second, the catalytic activity and the specificity of enzyme mimics were not sufficiently high, and must be further promoted for versatile applications. Thirdly, most of artificial enzymes were prepared with elaborate synthesis, and were too expensive for practical tools. It is noteworthy that, in order to obtain useful tools for practical applications, we do not have to strictly stick to the structures of naturally occurring enzymes. Rather, we can simply adopt the fundamental concepts they teach us, and take advantage of these results to design our target tools. Fortunately, in the course of the studies on enzyme models, we learned that the “proximity effects”, “cooperation of multiple catalysts”, “regulation of mutual orientation of reaction sites”, and “control of reaction fields” govern the reaction rate, and the effects of these factors are far more enormous than we expected before. In other words, we should be able to synthesize highly effective and practically useful artificial enzymes by attaching catalysts of high activity to substrate-binding molecules with these factors satisfactorily fulfilled. As discussed in Section 2, nanoarchitectonics can play significant roles here, since molecular structures of our tools must be precisely regulated in nanometer-scale for further developments of the field. In the following sections, the strategies leading to “practically useful artificial enzymes” as man-made tools will be described. 4 Developments of highly active catalysts for versatile reactions In artificial enzymes, target substrate is bound by a substrate-binding moiety, and then a catalyst being attached to this moiety transforms the substrate to desired products. In order to design practically useful artificial enzymes, the first requisite is to obtain highly eminent catalyst which allows target reactions to proceed promptly under designated conditions. It should be noted that these catalysts never have to be composed of the catalytic groups found in naturally occurring enzymes (i.e., side chains of amino acids and/or enzymatic cofactors). Rather, any kinds of catalysts (either organic or inorganic) are acceptable, as long as they satisfy the following requirements. The most crucial requirement is to obtain artificial enzyme which catalyzes the reaction we need. The catalysis must cover all the reactions relevant to our needs for daily lives, industry, medicine, and others. Secondly, the catalytic activity must be sufficiently high so that even enormously slow reactions must proceed at reasonable rates under the conditions employed. Thirdly, they must be stable under various conditions, and ideally show satisfactory selectivity. Lastly, they should be small in size, and easily connectable to substrate-binding moieties. Many excellent catalysts have been recently developed and applied to artificial enzymes. 4.1 Nanozymes as eminent catalysts 4.1.1 Nanoparticles showing remarkable catalytic activity Recently, nanoparticles showing very high catalytic activity were discovered as mimics of oxidase, catalase, superoxide dismutase, and others (Fig. 3 ) [122–128]. Their catalytic activities are unexpectedly large, and in some case comparable with those of enzymes. Accordingly, these particles are named as “nanozymes”, although they bind substrate simply by non-covalent adsorption without specific substrate-binding site. These findings made an epoch in the fields, since the catalytic activity is far larger than those of organic catalysts or metal complexes which were previously used for artificial enzymes. In 2007, it was found that ferromagnetic nanoparticles of Fe3O4 are enormously active to oxidize 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB), as well as di-azo-aminobenzene and o-phenylenediamine, with H2O2, and are reminiscent of peroxidase [129]. These nanoparticles were prepared by conventional methods (150 and 300 nm diameters by solvothermal method and 30 nm particles by co-precipitation method). The catalytic reactions followed typical Michaelis–Menten kinetics, and the activity of these nanoparticles was comparable with the activity of horseradish peroxidase (HRB). For TMB oxidation, for example, the kcat of the nanozyme is larger than the value of the enzyme, whereas the Km value was smaller. Thus, the nanozyme has stronger binding than the enzyme toward the substrate, and the catalytic transformation is faster. For the oxidation of H2O2 substrate, kcat of the nanozyme is larger, although Km is also larger. The activity decreased in the order that 30 nm > 150 nm > 300 nm. The smaller the size, the higher the catalytic activity, probably due to greater surface-to-volume ratio of smaller nanoparticles. Dextran-coated nanoparticles of CeO2 also efficiently catalyzed the oxidation in analogous manner [130,131]. These nanoparticles are advantageous in that, in contrast with Fe3O4 nanoparticles, the oxidation occurs even in the absence of H2O2, which suggest that O2 is directly used as the oxidant. The Cu(II) complex of guanosine monophosphate (GMP) oxidized various aromatic substrates such as phenol, naphthol, catechol and epinephrine [132]. When CuCl2 and GMP were mixed at pH 8, an amorphous metal-organic framework material was formed with molar ratio of 3:4 (Fig. 4 ). At the same mass concentration, the resultant Cu/GMP nanozyme has a higher Vmax than the enzyme laccase, which is a multicopper oxidase and important for biotechnology and environmental remediation. The Km is close to the value of laccase. The Cu(II) ion cannot be substituted by other metal ions. The reactions are environmentally friendly, since the addition of H2O2 is unnecessary and furthermore H2O2 is never formed in the course of the reactions. On the other hand, Au nanoparticles, protected by glucose, are a mimic of glucose oxidase, converting glucose to gluconic acid and H2O2 [133]. These particles are produced as a colloidal sol by reducing HAuCl4 in the presence of a large excess of glucose which acts as either reagent or protector. The catalytic activity in convertion from glucose to gluconic is comparable with the value of glucose oxidase. There are many other nanozymes for oxidation/reduction reactions and hydrolysis reactions (mimics of catalase, oxidase, peroxidase, superoxide dismutase, esterase, nuclease, phosphatase, protease and ferroxidase) [125–127]. They possess many advantages such as high stability, low-cost, simple preparation, and easy surface modification, and have been extensively applied to biosensing, bioimaging, tissue engineering, and therapeutics. The Co3O4 nanotubes with a large surface area were mimics showing triple-enzyme activity: oxidase-like activity, peroxidase-like activity and catalase-like activity [134]. Nanostructure of sheet-like FeS, prepared by a simple micelle-assisted synthetic method, was a mimic of peroxidase [135]. 4.1.2 Surface modification of nanozymes for improved functions By chemically modifying the surface of nanozymes and introducing appropriate functional groups thereto, the catalytic activity was further improved [136]. In an example, the catalytic activity of Fe3O4 nanozyme as a mimic of horseradish peroxidase was increased by introducing histidine residues onto its surface [137]. This modification was based on the fact that, in naturally occurring peroxidase, a distal imidazole of His42 holds H2O2 in the active site cavity through hydrogen-bond interactions, and this fixation is one of the significant factors for the remarkable activity of this enzyme (Fig. 5 ). The histidine-modified Fe3O4 nanozyme was prepared by solvothermal method. Briefly, FeCl3•6H2O was dissolved in ethylene glycol, and histidine and sodium acetate were added with continuous vigorous stirring. The mixture was sonicated for 10 min and then reacted at 200 °C for 12 h. Finally, the products were washed several times with ethanol and dried at 60 °C. The number of histidine on each Fe3O4 nanozyme (500 nm size) was around 4.2 × 107. Exactly as designed, the modification improved the apparent affinity (Km) to H2O2 by more than 10-fold, and enhanced the catalytic efficiency (kcat/Km) by 20-fold. By surface modification, an entirely new catalytic function (RNA hydrolysis) was provided to Au nanozyme which was otherwise inactive for this reaction (Fig. 6 ) [138]. First, Au nanoparticles were prepared with 1-sulfanyloctane on the surface. Then, this ligand was exchanged with another ligand (azacrown-functionalized thiol) to provide an azacrown ether as metal-binding site. Finally, the active nanozyme for RNA hydrolysis was prepared by adding Zn(II) or Cu(II) ion which catalyzes RNA hydrolysis. In another example, an RNA analog was hydrolyzed by grafting guanidine-based polymer brushes onto silica nanoparticles [139]. The catalysis was ascribed to the cooperation of guanidino groups. These methods are very attractive to prepare versatile nanozyme catalysts, although the activities accomplished there were rather small. Upon surface modification of nanozymes, molecularly imprinting technique (section 6.1) is very useful to provide substrate specificity [140,141]. In Fig. 7 , the specificity of Fe3O4 nanozymes was improved by molecular imprinting. First, 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB: the template) was adsorbed on Fe3O4 nanozymes, and this composite was treated with a monomer mixture (2.6:2.6:1.0) of acrylamide, N-isopropylacrylamide, and N,N’-methylenebisacrylamide (crosslinking agent), together with ammonium persulfate/tetramethylethylenediamine (radical initiator). Layers of imprinted hydrogels were prepared on the surface of nanoparticles. When necessary, a positively charged monomer (N-[3-(dimethylamino)propyl]methacrylamide or 2-acrylamido-2-methyl-1-propanesulfonic acid) was added to the monomer mixture. After washing away the template, the resulting cavities, formed in the imprinted polymer layer, rebound the template preferentially to the substrates other than TMB. By harnessing electrostatic interactions using the positively charged monomers, nearly 100-fold increase in selectivity was achieved for TMB substrate. Simply by treating glucose oxidase-mimicking gold nanoparticles with various DNAs, enantioselectivity was introduced [142,143]. The DNAs were adsorbed on the surface of the particles, and changed their conformations according to the conditions between random-coil structure and multi-stranded ordered structures (e.g., duplex, i-motif, and G-quadruplex). As the result, the catalytic behaviors of gold nanoparticles for the oxidation of glucose were modulated to induce enantioselectivity. Random-coiled DNA-capped nanoparticles preferentially catalyzed the oxidation of L-glucose, whereas structured DNA-capped nanoparticles showed higher activity toward D-glucose. Protamine-protected gold nanoclusters as peroxidase mimic were subjected to non-covalent surface modification [144]. These particles were prepared by mixing HAuCl4 and protamine sulfate, followed by the addition of NaOH. Interestingly, Hg(II) ion dramatically and selectively enhanced the peroxidase-like activity of these protamine-modified nanoparticles. In a proposed mechanism, Hg(II) binds to Au nanoparticles and assists the generation of cationic Au species and partly oxidized Au species (Auδ+). This effect was used to detect Hg(II) ion with very high sensitivity (detection limit of 1.16 nM). Other metal ions (e.g., Fe3+, Zn2+, Mn2+, Cu2+, Cd2+, Pb2+, and Ag+) hardly affected the analysis. 4.2 Assembling of DNA and peptide for synergetic catalysis Promotion of hemin catalysis by histidine in Fig. 5 was also mimicked by an entirely different organic system [145,146]. Hemin-containing nanoparticles were prepared by self-assembly of guanine-rich nucleic acid (GGGTAGGGCGGGTTGGG) and histidine-rich peptide (containing 32 His residues). In these nanoparticles (around 500 nm size), the nucleic acid strand folds into a high-order structure composed of base-stacked quartets, which binds hemin. On the other hand, the His-rich peptide provides the amino acid residues to activate the peroxidase activity of hemin. The synergistic effects of the nucleic acid and the peptide were so remarkable that the turnover number for H2O2-mediated oxidization of 2,2′-azinobis(3-ethylbenzothiazoline-6-sulfonic acid) as a widely employed substrate was close to the value of natural peroxidase. The catalytic efficiency (kcat/Km) of hemin-containing complex was 1.5 nM, which was almost identical to that of myoglobin. The kcat value was almost 2 orders of magnitude larger. 4.3 Hydrolysis of highly stable biopolymers (DNA and peptides) As molecular biology, biotechnology, and medicine make remarkable progresses, the importance of artificial enzymes to manipulate biomaterials is getting more crucial. New man-made tools are absolutely necessary. Among the main components of our body, both DNA and peptides are the most important, and must be appropriately manipulated. For a long time, however, no man-made tools were available for their manipulation, mainly because they are too stable and strongly resistant against hydrolytic scission. For example, the phosphodiester linkage in DNA has a half-life of two hundred million years! It was long believed to be impossible to hydrolyze DNA without using naturally occurring enzymes. In early 1990s, however, remarkable catalysis of Ce(IV) ion for DNA hydrolysis was discovered [147,148]. The acceleration of DNA hydrolysis by Ce(IV) ion is 1011 fold, reducing the half-life of one phosphodiester linkage to a few hours. Both single-stranded and double-stranded DNAs were efficiently hydrolyzed without specific base-preference. It was then found that Ce(IV)/EDTA complex shows a very unique substrate-specificity and hydrolyzes only single-stranded DNA (EDTA: N,N,N’,N’-ethylenediaminetetraacetate) [149,150]. Double-stranded DNA is hardly hydrolyzed by this complex. With the use of this substrate specificity, artificial restriction DNA cutters for site-selective scission of human genome were developed (see the Section 5.2). Amide linkages are also very stable (the half-life for its hydrolysis is 350–500 years) [151]. Of variety of transition metal ions investigated, Pd(II) ion (and its complexes also) are very active and hydrolyze amide bonds at reasonable rates under physiological conditions [152–154]. Ce(IV) ion is also active for amide hydrolysis [155]. Recently, microgels of poly(N-isopropylacrylamide) hydrolyzed activated amide linkages in anilide, although it contained no metal ions [156]. 5 New concepts for the design of substrate-binding sites possessing versatile properties In order to prepare practically useful artificial enzymes, substrate-binding moieties must be also improved. One factor to be solved is to obtain guest-binding sites which are applicable to variety of substrates. Chemical modification of well-known host molecules is one of the strategies. However, entirely new concepts have been also developed recently as described below. Another factor is to control the physicochemical properties in artificial enzymes to the properties which are the most suitable for target reaction. Most of previous hosts (e.g., cyclodextrins, cyclophanes, and others) employ hydrophobic interactions to bind substrates. However, physiological circumstances must be efficiently controlled according to target reaction, since hydrophobic environments are never always the best choice for the reactions. These factors will be discussed in this section. 5.1 Formation of specific reaction fields 5.1.1 Use of interior of nanoarchitectures In enzymatic catalysis, proteins provide reaction fields in which the chemical environments fairly suit the catalytic reactions [157]. Furthermore, spatial restraints in the cavities lead to the selective formation of a product of desired molecular size and structure. It was found that some of nanostructures in fact satisfactorily control the reaction rate and substrate specificity through this kind of mechanism [158–160]. A tetrahedral metal-ligand cluster Ga4L6 12– 1 [L = N,N’-bis(2,3-dihydroxybenzoyl)-1,5-diaminonaphthalene] was formed through spontaneous assembly in solutions (Fig. 8 ). This highly anionic cluster 1 encapsulated many neutral and cationic substrates within its hydrophobic interior cavity, and provided unique catalysis based on its microenvironmental effects [159]. The catalytic effect was remarkable especially on alkyl-alkyl reductive elimination from high-valent transition metal complexes (e.g., [Pt(Me3P)2(Me)3I] → [Pt(Me3P)2(Me)I + Me-Me]), which is the central elementary step in many transition-metal catalyzed bond formations. The reactions proceeded via a Michaelis-Menten–type mechanism, and the rate acceleration (kcat/kuncat) was as large as 1.9 × 107. Here, the microenvironments of interior of the supramolecular assembly play an essential role as an enzyme mimic. Consistently, blocking of the interior cavity of 1 with strongly encapsulated Et4P cation eliminated its accelerating effect. This modality has further been incorporated into a dual catalytic cross-coupling reaction ([MeI + Sn(Me)4 + KF] → [Me-Me + Sn(Me)3F + KI]). This reaction proceeds very efficiently, due to the cooperation of both the supramolecular microenvironment catalyst and the transition metal catalyst. Gold(I)-catalyzed cyclo-isomerization of an enyne was also catalyzed with significant selectivity by similar architectures, which is reminiscent of enzymatic catalysis [161–167]. Me3PAuCl was encapsulated into the Ga4L6 12– cluster (Me3PAu+⊂cluster). In the absence of the cluster, the major product of Me3PAuCl-catalyzed cycloisomerization is the OH-bearing compound (85% yield). Apparently, water molecules in the mixture notably participate to the reaction. However, the treatment of the enyne reagent with Me3PAu+⊂cluster, a diene product was instead produced as the major product (60% yield). Apparently, the hydrophobic interior of the cluster prevents the capture of reactive intermediates by water. The encapsulation imposes a mechanistic control that is never observed in bulk aqueous solution. Proton exchange reactions are also greatly promoted in the cavity [168]. 5.1.2 Use of higher-order structures of DNA DNA is a chiral molecule, and thus has a potential as asymmetric catalyst. In addition to well-known B-structure, DNA takes a variety of non-B structures (e.g., G-quadruplex and i-motif). In these three-dimensional structures, unique chirality of DNA is further magnified. In many cases, catalytically active metal complexes are combined with DNA, and their catalysis proceeds in the chiral environments of the DNA, resulting in enantioselectivity [169–171]. Two types of strategies are available. In the first strategy, a DNA-binding moiety is covalently attached to metal complex, and allows non-covalent binding of the complex to DNA. In the other type, metal complexes are directly bound to DNA through covalent linkages. In 2005, DNA was used for Cu(II)-catalyzed enantioselective Diels-Alder reaction (Fig. 9 ) [172]. The Cu(II)/DNA composite was prepared by the former strategy in which Cu(II) ion is coordinated to a ligand which bears a DNA-intercalating moiety (9-aminoacridine). The chirality of double-stranded DNA was transferred to the catalytic products. Quite interestingly, despite the invariance of intrinsic chirality of the DNA employed, the direction of enantiomeric excess (e.e.) of the Diels-Alder products was changed from positive to negative, depending on the structure of the ligand in the Cu(II) complexes. Since this finding was reported, a variety of DNA-based asymmetric catalysts involving a metal complex were reported in carbon-carbon or carbon-heteroatom bond-formations (Michael additions, Friedel-Crafts alkylation, and others) [173–182]. With the use of the second strategy, enantioselective Friedel-Crafts alkylation was also successfully performed [183]. When a 2,2′-bipyridine ligand was introduced to the inside of one of the two DNA strands, the e.e. value attained 86% under the optimized conditions. According to systematic studies, the disposition of the metal-binding site in the DNA duplex greatly affects the catalytic properties. Furthermore, an excellent enantioselective catalyst was constructed from salmon testes DNA (6 mM in base pairs) and Fe(III) complex of cationic meso-tetrakis(N-alkylpyridyl)porphyrin (75 μM) at pH 6.5 [184]. This artificial enzyme effectively catalyzed enantioselective cyclopropanation of styrene with ethyl diazoacetate as the carbene precursor. The catalysis is based on the promotion of carbene-transfer, as evidenced by the formation of a dimer of ethyl diazoacetate. This DNA/porphyrin hybrid catalyst promoted the carbene-transfer, since the porphyrin binds to the DNA groove and allow the access of active site to substrate. In another example, Friedel-Crafts alkylation/enantioselective protonation reactions by Cu(II) ion or its complexes were greatly accelerated by DNA [185]. Typical conditions were 0.15 mM of Cu(dmbipy)(NO3)2 and 1 mM (in base pairs) of salmon testes DNA at pH 5.0 and 4 °C. The magnitude of acceleration was >700-fold. This rate acceleration is in part due to the DNA acting as a pseudophase, analogous to micelles, in which all reaction components are concentrated to high effective molarities. G-quadruplexes are formed by stacking of two or more guanine tetrads of square planar structures in which four guanine bases spontaneously associate through Hoogsteen hydrogen bonding. They show asymmetric catalysis in Michaelis addition [186], Diels–Alder reactions [187,188], C–C bond formation [189,190], and sulfoxidation [191]. For example, a strand of 5′-AGGGAGGGCGCTGGGAGGAGGG-3′ sequence forms stable G-quadruplex, and its 12th T was substituted with a deoxyuridine derivative. To the C5-position of this deoxyuridine, a bipyridine ligand was covalently bound via linkers of different lengths (Fig. 10 ) [186]. The Cu(II) complexes of these modified quadruplexes exhibited high rate acceleration and stereoselectivity in Michaelis addition. The position of modification, topology of quadruplex, nature of ligand, and length of the linker strongly affected the catalytic performance. The (+)-enantiomers were obtained with e.e. of up to 75%. Interestingly, when the position of modification in the G-quadruplex was changed from the 12th nucleotide to 10th nucleotide, enantioselectivity was reversed and (-)-enantiomers were preferentially formed (up to 92% e.e.). By arranging these DNA parts in programmed fashion, still more advanced artificial enzymes should be able to be obtained. As the joints to connect the parts, catenanes are especially promising, since two rings of single-stranded DNA are mechanically interlocked without covalent linkages, and dynamically move each other. Various nanosized parts (not only DNA assemblies but also other nanomaterials) can be precisely placed in space with sufficient molecular flexibility [192]. Recently, facile methods to synthesize catenanes and DNA rings in high yield and high selectivity were reported and should facilitate these researches furthermore [193–195]. It was also shown that Z-DNA can be stably constructed under physiological conditions with the use of topological constraint [196]. In contrast with conventional B-DNA of right-handed helical structure, Z-DNA has left-handed double-helical structure, and its unique structure should open new fields in DNA-based chiral catalysis. 5.2 Use of oligonucleotides and its analogs to bind DNA for desired transformation With the progress of biotechnology, artificial enzymes to convert DNA (and RNA) to desired forms are getting more important. Critical factor of concern is site-specificity in which only one site in huge DNA must be altered to desired form with the other portions kept intact. The simplest strategy to recognize a predetermined site in DNA is to use complementary oligonucleotide as site-recognizing site and attach an appropriate catalyst to this oligonucleotide for site-selective reaction. On this strategy, various artificial enzymes to transform DNA have been already constructed [120,197,198]. For more versatile applications, however, conventional oligonucleotides are not completely satisfactory in terms of binding-strength, stability, and other properties. To solve these problems, oligonucleotides were variously modified by chemical means. Furthermore, DNA analogs having different structures from naturally occurring ones, were synthesized. The most widely employed analog is peptide nucleic acid (PNA; Fig. 11 A). This DNA analog is a condensation polymer of N-aminoethylglycine, and composed of poly(N-(2-aminoethyl)glycine) backbone [199,200]. Nucleobases are attached to the central nitrogen atoms, and PNA binds to the complementary DNA (and RNA) through Watson-Crick rules. In contrast with negatively charged DNA, the backbone of PNA is electrostatically neutral. Thus, when PNA forms a duplex with complementary DNA or RNA, there is no electrostatic repulsion between the two complementary strands. This is highly in contrast with destabilization of DNA-DNA and DNA-RNA duplexes by this electrostatic repulsion. Accordingly, PNA/DNA and PNA/RNA duplexes are far more stable than the corresponding DNA/DNA and DNA/RNA complexes. This DNA analog is resistant against nucleases and proteases. In order to construct practical artificial enzymes, however, simple “complementary DNA strategy”, described above, is not usually useful, since DNA substrate mostly exists in the form of a double helix. Triple-helix formation is available only for the recognition of homopurine/homopyrimidine sequences in double-stranded DNA [120]. As a solution to this problem, pseudo-complementary PNA (pcPNA) has been developed [199,201]. Its backbone is identical with that of conventional PNA, but specially designed nucleobases (2,6-diaminopurine (D) and 2-thiouracil (Us)) are used, respectively, in place of natural nucleobases A and T (Fig. 11B). These pseudo-complementary bases [202] strongly bind to natural bases T and A. Importantly, a D-T pair is even more stable than A-T pair, since three hydrogen bonds are formed between them (additional hydrogen-bond is formed between 2-NH2 of D and 2-O of T). On the other hand, D-Us pair is unstable, because the 2-NH2 of D and 2-S of Us sterically repel each other upon the formation of this pair. Because of these properties, duplexes between two complementary pcPNA strands are very unstable. Thus, they can locally unravel double-stranded DNA at target site and invade it to form invasion complexes (double-duplex invasion) [201–204]. Note that these two pcPNA strands are necessarily complementary to each other, and the formation of pcPNA/pcPNA homo-duplexes competitively suppresses double-duplex invasion. Only with the use of pcPNAs, this homohybridization is successfully minimized, and double-duplex invasion occurs at the target site through Watson-Crick rule. It was reported that all the nucleobases in PNA do not have to be necessarily replaced with pseudo-complementary bases for the invasion. Rather, “partially substituted pcPNAs” also show double-duplex invasion. Still more interestingly, with the use of partially substituted pcPNA, only one strand (not a pair of strands) can successfully invade double-stranded DNA [205]. This finding should greatly facilitate the design of invasion systems for further developments of the field. By using double-duplex invasion of pcPNA, completely chemistry-based artificial restriction DNA cutters involving no proteins were fabricated (Fig. 11C) [206–208]. The most important point in their design is that the binding sites of two pcPNA strands (both involving 15 nucleobases; blue lines) are laterally shifted each other by several bases (e.g., 5 nucleobases). Thus, single-stranded portions (red parts) are formed at desired sites in both strands of DNA. These sites are selectively cut by either Ce(IV)/EDTA complex or nuclease S1, both of which hydrolyze only single-stranded DNA. It is noteworthy that the above system recognizes 20-bp sequence in DNA (one 10 bp sequence involving two pcPNAs + two 5 bp sequences involving one pcPNA). Accordingly, this man-made cutter cuts human genome (3 × 109 bp) selectively at only one site (420 > 3 × 109) [208–210]. Importantly, the double-duplex invasion of pcPNA occurs more efficiently in cells than in aqueous solutions [211], due to so-called “molecular crowding effect” (the inside of cells is largely occupied by proteins and other biomolecules, and thus its physicochemical properties are much different from bulk aqueous phase). As the substrate binding site in artificial enzymes, aptamers are also promising. They are single-stranded DNA molecules that can bind their target molecules with high affinity and specificity [212]. These man-made antibodies are screened by a SELEX procedure (Systematic Evolution of Ligands by Exponential enrichment) from a random library comprised of an enormous number of different oligonucleotides. To an aptamer, hemin/G-quadruplex as oxidation catalyst was conjugated [213]. The substrate dopamine was bound by the aptamer, which was prepared for the purpose. The resultant high local concentrations led to enhanced catalytic activity in enantioselective oxidization by H2O2. As expected, saturation kinetics was observed. 6 Improved design of artificial enzymes 6.1 Molecular imprinting technique In molecular imprinting, functional monomer(s) are polymerized in the presence of a template molecule, and the whole structure is frozen in polymeric structures (Fig. 12 ) [121,214–216]. In this snap-shot, the template is memorized in terms of spatial structure, positions of functional groups, and other physicochemical properties. The interactions between the template and monomers in the polymerization mixtures can be either covalent or noncovalent. If a substrate for catalytic reaction (or a molecule having a similar structure as the substrate) is employed as template, the resultant molecular imprinting polymer should be an artificial enzyme for the reaction. Molecular imprinting method was first reported in 1972 [217], and thereafter the relevant science grew remarkably. By using target substrate as template, various artificial enzymes showing high selectivity have been already fabricated [121,218,219]. High catalytic activity is successfully accomplished, since the cavity in the polymers selectively binds the corresponding substrate, and furthermore catalytic groups (derived from functional monomers) are placed complementarily to the substrate. For example, a catalytically active polymer for the isomerization of benzisoxazole was prepared in a tailor-made fashion [220]. In the presence of indole (having analogous structure to benzisoxazole) as the template, 4-vinylpyridine and methacrylic acid were copolymerized with ethylene glycol dimethacrylate (crosslinker) by using 2,2′-azobisisobutyronitrile (radical initiator). Compared with uncatalyzed reaction, the rate was enormously enhanced (e.g., >104 fold). By a similar strategy, various organic and inorganic catalysts were prepared by molecular imprinting. Usually, both reaction rate and selectivity were promoted [220–223]. A detailed review on this subject was recently reported [121]. In this strategy, however, catalytic residues from functional monomers also exist outside the cavity, leading to non-specific catalysis. In order to accomplish still higher selectivity, catalytic sites should exist only in the binding pocket. For this purpose, a new post-molecular modification methodology was developed (Fig. 13 ) [121,216,224–256]. For the cleavage of atrazine (6-chloro-N2-ethyl-N4-isopropyl-1,3,5-triazine-2,4-diamine), two functional groups (carboxylic acid and sulfonic acid) are necessary. The carboxylate recruits the substrate through electrostatic interaction, whereas the sulfonic acid is acid catalyst. In the molecular imprinting, polymerizable atrazine analogues bearing an allyl or a styryl group via a disulfide bond at the 6-position were copolymerized with methacrylic acid (functional comonomer to provide a carboxylate) and styrene/divinylbenzene mixture (crosslinkers). After the polymerization, the atrazine moiety, which was covalently bound to the polymer matrix, was removed by reducing the disulfide bond. Then, the remaining thiol group was oxidized to generate sulfonic acid (the catalytically active group). By this post-imprinting treatment, the catalytic residue for the decomposition of atrazine was selectively introduced only to the catalytic site. As the result, highly efficient catalysis was accomplished with minimal production of undesired byproducts. In order to prepare artificial enzymes showing high catalytic activity, use of stable transition state analog as template for molecular imprinting is a promising strategy. This template resembles the transition state of catalytic reaction, but is sufficiently stable to be employed for molecular imprinting. If we can prepare a molecule which binds the transition state more strongly than the initial state, this molecule should be a sophisticated catalyst for the reaction. This methodology was first proposed by Jencks [103] and later successfully used to construct so-called “catalytic antibodies” [227,228]. Since then, transition state analog technology was widely used in molecular imprinting [229–233]. For the hydrolysis of anilide, a phosphate template was used as stable transition analog, since the hydrolysis of anilide involves nucleophilic attack of OH− towards the carbonyl center to form a tetrahedral carbon atom which can be mimicked by the tetracoordinated phosphorus atom. By using molecular imprinting technique, a mimic of chymotrypsin was synthesized (Fig. 14 ) [234]. This enzyme has Ser, His, and Asp residues at the active site, and these three residues form charge-relay system (Ser-His-Asp triad) to efficiently hydrolyze amide substrates (see Fig. 14). In order to hydrolyze p-nitroanilide of phenylalanine, phenyl-1-(N-benzyloxycarbonylamino)-2-(phenyl)ethyl phosphonate was used as the transition state analog. In the presence of this template, N-methacryloyl-L-histidine, N-methacryloyl-L-aspartic acid, and N-methacryloyl-L-serine (functional monomers) and ethylene glycol dimethacrylate (crosslinking agent) were polymerized. The polymer, obtained after the removal of the template, efficiently hydrolyzed p-nitroanilide of phenylalanine, and the reaction followed pseudo-first-order kinetics. Stereospecificity and substrate selectivity were also observed. The reactive functionalities were properly orientated in the super-crosslinked macroporous polymer matrix, and selectively bound the substrate and hydrolyzed it for highly efficient catalysis. Other artificial enzymes having imidazole moiety were fabricated on multiwalled carbon nanotubes by molecular imprinting technology [235]. In the presence of phenyl L-benzyloxycarbonylamino-4-methoxybenzyl phosphonate (template), methacryloyl-L-histidine was polymerized with ethylene glycol dimethacrylate (crosslinking agent) and vinyl functionalized multiwalled carbon nanotubes by thermal polymerization technique. The polymer hydrolyzed p-nitrophenyl esters of Z-L-phenylalanine. 6.2 Nanoarchitectonics for the construction of artificial enzymes Recent developments of nanoarchitectonics have enabled the construction of artificial enzymes through spontaneous assembly of small components. This entirely new strategy has several advantages. First, functional groups are placed at desired places in the course of self-aggregation [170]. Thus, complicated artificial enzymes, which are difficult to prepare by synthetic approach, can be rather easily constructed. Furthermore, the systems should be able to be effectively optimized through systematic changes of the structures of components (and of the resultant nanostructures). Second, the catalytic activity can be easily controlled by outer stimulus (e.g., temperature and pH). In contrast with most of previously studied artificial enzymes, the whole structures of nanoarchitectures (and their physicochemical properties) can be straightforwardly altered by these stimuli, since they are primarily composed of labile non-covalent interactions. These properties are difficult to be provided by other methodology. 6.2.1 Easy construction of complicated catalytic systems The following model of glutathione peroxidase (GPx) is a typical example [236.]. This enzyme protects our body from oxidative damage. One of its roles is to decompose hydroperoxide using the oxidation of glutathione (GSH) to glutathione disulfide (GS-SG): 2 GSH + H2O2 → GS-SG + 2 H2O. The parent nanostructure to prepare its mimic is composed of β-cyclodextrin and a guest molecule which bears both adamantane and three long aliphatic chains (Fig. 15 ). The formation of this stable host–guest complex is driven by hydrophobic interaction between the adamantly moiety and the hydrophobic cavity of CD. The resultant amphiphilic host-guest compound was slowly injected into deionized water under sonication, resulting in the formation of giant nanotubes with a length of 20 μm. The mimic of GPx was prepared by attaching appropriate functional groups to these β-cyclodextrins. In the specific binding site of naturally occurring GPx, substrate GSH is stabilized by two arginine residues (Arg57, Arg103), and a catalytic selenocysteine is located there. In order to mimic this catalytic selenocysteine, β-cyclodextrin bearing selenonic acid (CD-SeO3H) was designed. To imitate the two Arg residues, guanidine-functionalized β-cyclodextrin (guanidino-CD) was also prepared (the guanidino groups bind GSH through noncovalent interactions with carboxylate groups). When these two types of modified β-cyclodextrins were mixed, self-assembly proceeded and a nanotube was obtained. The selenol group and guanidino groups were located on the surface of the nanotube wall. This artificial enzyme was active for the reduction of H2O2. Still more interestingly, the activity was further promoted by using molecular imprinting technique (6.1) during the process of self-aggregation (Fig. 16 ). First, CD-SeO3H was covalently conjugated to GSH (CD-Se-SG), and this conjugate was used as the template to create a complementary binding site of GSH on a nanotube. After pre-organization of the GSH unit of CD-Se-SG with the guanidine moieties of two guanidino-CD molecules, a similar self-assembly process as above was carried out, and the mutual conformations of these two kinds of CD derivatives were fixed on the surface of nanotubes. As the result, the catalytic selenol group was successfully oriented in the GSH binding site in proximity to the reacting sulfhydryl moiety of GSH. The two guanidino groups were also precisely placed. This structure is reminiscent of the active site of natural glutathione peroxidase. In fact, the imprinted nanotubes showed 2.6 fold larger activity, compared with non-imprinted nanotubes. 6.2.2 Control of catalytic activity by external stimulus Reversible regulation of catalytic activity is an important feature of natural enzymes which cannot be easily accomplished by most of artificial catalytic systems. Nanoarchitectonics is advantageous for this regulation, since the whole structures of nanoarchitectures can be changed by outer stimuli under appropriate design, and accordingly the catalytic functions can be regulated. An artificial hydrolase showing pH-switchable activity was prepared with the use of peptides which have many Lys residues and show pH-dependent conformational change between random coil and β-sheet [237]. Catalytic His residue was introduced to the terminus of this pH-responsive peptide. At neutral pH, the Lys groups are protonated, and the resultant positive charge causes a repulsion to prevent the hydrogen bonding of the strands of the hairpin. Thus, the peptide adopts a random coil configuration, and the intermolecular catalysis by its His residue is inefficient. However, the increase in the pH reduces this repulsion due to the deprotonation of Lys groups, and leads the peptide to β-sheet configuration. The alternation of Val and Lys in the backbone results in one face of the sheet being hydrophobic and the other one being hydrophilic. A second layer of hairpins causes the formation of a bilayer with the hydrophobic faces of the two layers facing. The β-sheet self-assembles to form long fibrils with the hydrophobic edge, and His residues extending in an ordered array for notable esterase activity. The edge of the self-assembled fibrillar structure is hydrophobic, and provides a unique vantage point for the installation of a catalytic site. In fact, the reaction followed Michaelis-Menten kinetics (kcat = 0.07 s−1, Km =3.65 mM). This switching of catalytic activity was reversibly repeated many times by changing the pH between 6 and 9. The pH-dependent switching of catalytic activity was also accomplished by incorporating a biological cofactor heme-B to self-assembling peptides [238]. The effects of morphology (micelles vs. fibers) using peptide amphiphiles of the sequence c16-xyL3K3-CO2H. Here, c16 is a palmitoyl moiety, and xy represents the heme binding region. It was found that the heme active site binds carbon monoxide in both micelles and fibers, demonstrating that the heme active site in both morphologies is accessible to small molecules for catalysis. Its peroxidase activity was clearly observed in heme-containing micelles, but was significantly reduced in heme-containing fibers. In addition to simple steric hindrance, the morphology strongly induces different heme coordination environments. With appropriate design, the nanostructure can be altered with temperature change, and thermo-responsive model of glutathione peroxidase (in the previous section) was successfully obtained [239,240]. Thermo-sensitive catalysis was also achieved simply by using temperature dependent complex formation of cucurbituril (a cyclic host molecule) to encapsulate catalytically active molecule [118]. It was found that self-assembly of a peptide NH2-GSGQQKFQFQFEQQ-amide hydrolyzed 4-nitrophenyl acetate [241]. More interestingly, the activity was further promoted, when the hydrolase catalytic sites (His or Arg) were embedded in a matrix of peptide nanofibers. 6.3 Use of multimers of proteins for the construction of artificial enzymes Many proteins take higher-order structures, which can increase the complexity of the protein structure and also control the activity. Dimerization of proteins was used as a convenient way to construct metalloenzyme models [242]. In an attempt, the Lactococcal multidrug resistance Regulator (LmrR) was selected as scaffold to accommodate catalyst (Fig. 17 ). This transcriptional repressor is a dimeric protein (13.5 kDa per subunit), and has a large flat hydrophobic pore at the center of the dimer. Active site can be placed in this hydrophobic pore, which is large enough to incorporate a metal complex and still leave enough space for substrate-binding. An artificial metalloenzyme was prepared by introducing two Cu(II) complexes (one for each monomer protein) through the conjugation to a cysteine residue on the protein. Based on the crystal structure, positions 19 and 89 were selected for the covalent attachment of a Cu(II) complex because these positions are located at the ends of the hydrophobic pore. Phenanthroline- and bipyridine-based ligands were connected to the cysteines at these positions. When the Diels–Alder reaction of azachalcone with cyclopentadiene was carried out with these catalysts, the e.e. value was around 50% for the endo product (endo/exo 92:8). With anchoring of the phenanthroline ligand to the 89 position, the e.e. was increased to 97% (endo/exo 95:5). Enantioselective Friedel-Crafts alkylation of indoles was accomplished also by using the dimer of LmrR [243]. 7 Monolayer-type artificial enzyme (L-zyme) Unlike examples mentioned above, enzyme-like reaction enhancements can be done by modifying dielectric environments for reactions instead of designing materials structures. Catalysts can promote reactions efficiently by modifying reactant structures and shifting physicochemical natures of reacting molecules. The latter effect is sometimes obtainable by changing reaction environments, which can be accomplished through designing interfacial environment. Langmuir-monolayers with appropriate functional groups at the air-water interface can promote some reactions like artificial enzyme. This type of artificial enzyme with this new concept is named as a Langmuir enzyme (L-zyme) [244]. Molecular interactions are known to be significantly emphasized as compare with those in aqueous solutions [245,246]. Although the binding constant between guanidinium and phosphate stays only at 1.4 M−1 in water [247], the corresponding bonding constants are increased to 102 - 104 M−1 [248] at disordered interfaces of aqueous micelles and lipid bilayers and are enhanced even to 106 - 107 M−1 at macroscopic static interface of the air-water interface [249]. Similarly, significantly enhanced binding constants are generally observed for a wide range of guest molecules such as sugars [250,251], amino acids [252], nucleic acid bases [253,254], nucleotides [255,256], and peptides [257,258]. These promoted molecular recognition is originated in enhanced nature of hydrogen bonding at interfacial media between media with different dielectric constants. Significant contributions of low-dielectric medium to molecular interaction at the air-water interface was also proved by quantum chemical calculations [259–261]. Therefore, Langmuir monolayers at the air-water interface provide media for strengthened molecular recognition, which is advantageous nature for artificial enzyme. Peculiar features at the air-water interface are found for other equilibrium constants such as acid dissociation and base protonation [262,263]. Protonation constant of amino group of lysine residue is usually 10.5 in aqueous solution and is shifted to 9.4 at the surface of aqueous vesicles. However, embedding the same lysine residue at the air-water interface shifts the protonation constant to around 5 [264]. This remarkable shift of protonation constant of amino group is attributed to stabilization of neutral species in non-polar environment at the air-water interface. This huge shift of equilibrium constant enables lysine side chain to remain in its basic neutral amino form even at ambient pH conditions (Fig. 18 ). Therefore, Langmuir monolayer with lysine residue can work as base-catalyst for hydrolysis of ester substrates [244]. This is regarded as Langmuir enzyme (L-zyme). In addition, mechanical optimization for chiral discrimination of amino acids [265,266] and discrimination between thymine and uracil [267] with Langmuir monolayers have been demonstrated as well as molecular machine [268–270] controls including guest capturing at the air-water interface [271,272]. Such high capability of Langmuir monolayer for dynamic motions would be useful for control of artificial enzyme actions such as substrate capture and product release. There are still many rooms for exploration of artificial enzyme designs in Langmuir systems at the air-water interface. 8 Future perspective Developments of functional materials systems with capability of conversions of materials, energies, and various signals are important keys in science and technology for various problems in current society. Catalysis is the main concept to efficiently promote such conversions. As the most sophisticated systems to achieve various conversions, biological systems are well developed where biological catalysts, enzymes, play important roles. Therefore, exploration of catalytic systems with bio-like functions is reasonable to create advanced conversion systems for various demands. From these viewpoints, this review overviews artificial enzymes from their basics to functional applications and fore front research on the basis of molecular and nanoscopic structural designs. As seen in the listed examples, nanoarchitectonics for artificial enzymes needs considerations with knowledge in various research fields including organic chemistry, supramolecular chemistry, materials science, nanotechnology, and biology. These approaches may be regarded as good model cases to explore construction of functional materials systems from nano-units and molecules The concept of artificial enzymes is initiated simply as modeling of biological catalysis. However, their basic ideas can be potentially expanded to various conversion systems such as industrial catalysts, environmental catalysts, electrochemical catalysts, and photocatalysts. In these expanded applications, nanoarchitectonics concept for constructing functional systems from molecular and nanoscopic units would have crucial contributions. Nanoarchitected catalytic systems can be of course used in non-biological conditions. Therefore, further exploration of the artificial enzyme strategies with the nanoarchitectonics concept would lead to developments of various conversion systems that can be potentially used for many purposes even with industrial scales. Most of research efforts on artificial enzymes still stay in basic-level. Efficiency and specificity of enzymatic reactions in artificial enzymes may exceed those for natural enzymes in lab-level research. However, true gains of artificial enzymes in practical stage have to be realized with more efforts on engineering aspects. Potentials of artificial enzymes for practical and industrial applications would rely on their superiority in stability and recyclability. In cases of natural enzymes, these aspects have been compensated by immobilizing them in nanostructured materials such as mesoporous materials [273–275] and layered films [276,277] where tolerances to external disturbances including high temperatures and non-neutral pH are generally enhanced with limited degree. On the other hand, artificial enzymes can be nanoarchitected with highly resistant materials to give catalytic performances even under severe conditions. Therefore, artificial enzymes may be more suitable for enzyme-like advance catalytic functions in practical and industrial purposes. coredata.dc:description: Conversions of materials, energies, and various signals are important keys in science and technology to solve various problems in current society. Catalysis is the main concept to efficiently promote such conversions. As the most sophisticated systems to achieve various conversions, biological systems have been satisfactorily developed where biological catalysts, enzymes, play important roles. Therefore, catalytic systems with bio-like functions reasonably create advanced conversion systems for various demands. In this review article, basics of artificial enzymes and their recent progresses are overviewed on the basis of emerging concept, nanoarchitectonics. First, classical scientific efforts and basics for enzyme models are described, and then practically applicable artificial enzymes are presented. The latter part involves nanomaterials, DNA and peptides, modifications of their nanoarchitectures, and constructions of complicated and stimuli-responsive systems. We expect that overviewing artificial enzymes with the nanoarchitectonics concept would be useful to get intuitions for catalysts designs and their syntheses.
coredata.dc:title: Nanoarchitectonics to prepare practically useful artificial enzymes
